introduction.p: The top and bottom margins of a poster are 8 cm and the side margins are each 4 cm. The area of printed material on the poster is fixed at 200 square centimeters. Our goal will be to determine the dimensions of a poster that does this with minimum size.

image.description: Diagram of a square divided by vertical and horizontal lines into smaller rectangles, with the words “printed material” centered in the middle region.

statement.p: Label the dimensions of the printed material on the poster in with variables x and y.

figure.caption: Dimensions of the printed material on the poster.

image.description: Diagram of a square divided into rectangular margins around a central region labeled “printed material.” The top margin is labeled x, the right margin y, the left margin 4, the bottom margin 8, and the top-left interior segment is labeled 8.

statement.p: Determine a formula A(x,y) for the area of the poster. Then, give a formula describing the constraint regarding printed material that must be satisfied when creating this poster.

solution.p: We seek to minimize A(x,y) = (x+8)(y+16) = xy+16x+8y+128. That could be made very small by, for example, choosing x=0 and y=0. However, the constraint we face is that printed material must be 200 square centimeters. That is, xy=200.

statement.p: Write the function A found in part (b) as a function of the single variable x. Over what domain should we consider this function?

solution.p:
Solving xy=200 gives \displaystyle y=\frac{200}{x}. Substituting this into A(x,y) gives
A(x) = x\frac{200}{x}+16x+8\frac{200}{x}+128 = 16x + \frac{1600}{x}+ 328.
The domain of this function is 0 < x < \infty. That is, in theory, we can choose x or y to be extremely small (but positive) and then the other variable would be quite large.

statement.p: Find the dimensions of the poster with the smallest area.

solution.p: First, we find critical numbers. But A'(x) = 16 - 1600x^{-2} so that A'(x)=0 exactly when 16x^{2} = 1600. That is, when x=\pm 10. Since x=-10 is not in the domain, only x=10 is a critical number. To see that this is a global minimum, a first derivative sign chart can be drawn.

figure.caption: A first derivative sign chart for A(x)=16x + \frac{1600}{x}+ 328.

image.description: Sign chart on a number line for A′(x), with tick marks at 0 and 10. The derivative is negative to the left of 10, zero at 10, and positive to the right.
